EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────────
### Shared Smelting Furnaces Automation Network
Consists of two stone furnaces positioned at (0.0, 0.0) and (5.0, 0.0), each served by adjacent burner‑inserters and connected to wooden chests. This network manages the input and output of smelting operations.

### Iron Ore Mining Automation Setup
Consists of a burner‑mining drill located at (–15.0, –50.0) paired with a nearby wooden chest at (–13.5, –51.5). This setup is integrated into a transport‑belt network that efficiently distributes the mined ore.

### Steam Power Generation System
Centered on a boiler at (8.0, 20.5) equipped with connection points at approximately (8.5, 18.5) and (8.5, 22.5), this system powers multiple steam engines placed at (0.5, 9.5), (18.5, 11.5), (1.5, 13.5), (13.5, 14.5), (19.5, 14.5), (22.5, 18.5), (17.5, 20.5), (12.5, 21.5) and (4.5, 23.5). Note that an additional steam engine intended for this network remains unplaceable because of severe congestion and obstructions in the boiler zone.

### Automation Research Lab
Features a laboratory configured for automation science pack research. The lab is currently experiencing unstable power connectivity, affecting its operation.

### Electrical, Transport, and Fluid Infrastructure
An integrated backbone comprised of electrical poles (organized into electricity groups), numerous belt groups, and various pipe groups. These interconnected systems manage the coordinated flow of power, materials, and fluids across the map.

### Offshore Pump and Fluid Network
Consists of an offshore pump positioned at (0.5, 30.5) that feeds water into the fluid system via a network of connected pipe groups.

ERROR TIPS
────────────────────────────
• Persistent Extra Steam Engine Placement Issue  
  – The extra steam engine remains unplaceable due to severe congestion around the boiler area. Overlapping burner‑inserters and misaligned transport belts are obstructing the designated buildable zone (near approximately (8.5, 22.5)).  
  – Recommendation: Conduct a thorough manual inspection of the entire boiler zone and its connection interfaces, then remove or reposition interfering entities. Alternatively, consider relocating the extra steam engine to a less congested area or modifying the boiler layout to ensure adequate clearance.

• Fuel Supply Shortages in Burner‑Powered Entities  
  – Several burner‑inserters and the burner‑mining drill are repeatedly flagged as “out of fuel” or “waiting for source items,” which can disrupt continuous operation.  
  – Recommendation: Ensure that fuel sources are placed immediately adjacent to these burner‑powered machines and verify that the transport‑belt routing efficiently delivers fuel to all required stations.

• Steam Engine Connectivity and Fluid Input Issues  
  – Multiple steam engines report issues such as “not connected to power network” and “no input liquid,” compromising the overall performance of the power generation system.  
  – Recommendation: Review the electrical wiring and fluid piping arrangements. Reconfigure connection points and clear any obstructions to secure reliable network and fluid supplies for each steam engine.

• Laboratory Power Instability  
  – The Automation Research Lab continues to experience unstable power connectivity, affecting its research capabilities.  
  – Recommendation: Reassess the placement and wiring of nearby electrical poles and related power infrastructure to stabilize the lab’s power supply.
